Recharging batteries in smart phones should be done without a case in order to keep the temperatures of the battery as low as possible and removing the case is easy but installing it will find you fighting with overly soft rubber parts that get mangled until you play with it for quite a while. I find it uncomfortable to hold the phone to my ear because of the plastic edges on the case and all around quality seems lacking. I don't get the hype.

    Rating: 5

    2012-03-30: This car navigation dock rocks. It connects to the vehicle for charging your phone: You slip the phone in, push the latch [containing the usb plug,] the phone turns on, charges as required, and a specialized navigation panel pops up on the phone screen. You can still navigate to other areas on the phone by using the return symbol on the screen. That takes you off the specialized nav panel and you can then navigate the phone as normal. A plus: As soon as you unmount the phone, it remembers your car's location. You can with a free download in the Market then find your way back to the car. It remembers your coordinates automatically! On occasion when I've forgotten where I parked, I found the app to be quite accurate. Also, you can even take a picture of your location as well on the specialized app. NOTE: This dock is ONLY for the Razr. It will not work with other Motorola phones, like the Bionic.

    Rating: 5

    2012-03-08: I bought this dock for my Motorola Droid Razr Maxx. The dock works with both the Razr and the Razr Maxx. There is a snap on piece of plastic you remove to use it with the Maxx. This dock securely attaches to the windshield, holds the phone securely in place, charges the phone, and transmits sound via the charging cable to a 3.5 mm jack that can be attached to your car stereo's Aux In (if your car stereo is equipped).The dock functions well, is appealing to the eye, and I love the navigation screen.Con's: Without a case to bulk up the Razr Maxx, the phone will fall out when you release the sliding side dock-in port, which can be a distraction.With a decent hard case on your phone, the dock holds the phone well, works properly and does not release the phone to fall down in your car, when you release the side sliding dock-in port.Overall, I'd recommend this dock. However, get a hard case for your Razr Maxx and the Roadster for speaker phone and FM transmission and you'll enjoy it more than without those other accessories.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-13: This window mount for my Motorola Razor met all my needs. It is great for traveling and using the map app. It also make for a good hands free mount.

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-04: This dock is amazing. The insert comes out so my RAZR with Otterbox case fits in it. I don't have to take the case off --just pop it in. You will really like this dock. You may want to get an audio cable that has a noise filter to clean up the signal with power applied and playing music or listening to audio books. Mine screamed until I got one.

    Rating: 5

    2012-01-08: With my Droid X, the phone snapped easily into the dock, and the "Car Dock" software interface was friendly, easy to navigate and customizable.Motorola took a significant step backwards with the dock for the Razr. Probably to facilitate "skins", getting a naked phone into the dock requires wrestling with the position so the charging plug will slide in. Its frustrating. And the "car Dock" software is actually less capable than the Droid X (possibly to reduce direct interaction with the Razr's functions while driving).Love the Razr, but not the dock.

    Rating: 2

    Rating: 5

    2011-11-30: Have now used this dock several times, and have none of the issues other reviewers have. Slides easily in and out, allows me to navigate, search, play music, make and receive calls while driving and charge the Razr...which is about all I would ever do while driving. Allows my bluetooth headset voice to talk and listen...I have a Sound ID Six bluetooth headset. Pricey...yes, a bit for a car dock. Charging cord also has an additional slot to charge an mp3 player I believe? This dock also allows for the Motorola car finder app to pop up automatically once you remove the phone from the dock so you can later find your car in case you've forgotten where you parked. The dock does not allow for sending or receiving text messages which is a wonderful safety feature in this wild and crazy driving world we find ourselves in. So, is it fantastic, no. Does it work well, yes.

    Rating: 4

    2012-05-08: I received this mount today. There are some good features with this mount.1. The instructions for use are very clear abut how to slide the USB adapter to plug and unplug the phone. I had to wiggle it just a bit to make sure it lined up, but once I plugged it in, the phone switched to the car mode with no problem. Removing it was easy also. I believe a bit of care and not being too rough when mounting/unmounting the phone will help to ensure a long life for this product.2. The adapter plate, while a bit hard to remove, was not too hard. The curve of the holder is what gave me the most difficulty. I did not want to break it while removing it. The best thing seems to be work from one corner. Once that is loose, move to the other corner on the same end. After the two corners are loose, it will slide right out. With the adapter plate removed, the mount is perfect for use with my Droid Razr while it is in the case I had purchased for it. If I decide to remove the case later, I will just need to put the adapter plate back in and it will be the right size for the phone then.3. The ball mount: I have a dash beanbag style mount for a Garmin GPS. Instead of using the windshield mount or the disk to make it dash-mounted, I decided to pop the Garmin mount off the ball on the beanbag. It was the perfect size to then pop into the back of the phone mount. I now have my phone set up with my preferred mount. (The Garmin will use a separate vent-clip mount I had been using for my old Droid phone).4. The charger: I like the dual adapter. It will let me plug a second USB device in without having to use a separate power outlet adapter.Overall, I am well pleased with this purchase. If it holds up as well as I think it should, I would consider it a good purchase.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 1

    2012-12-15: Given the positive reviews on this product, I was confident to order it. However, when I tried to plug my Note II into the dock to charge, it does not even mate with the micro USB on the dock. I was a little perplexed as to why, so I plugged the micro USB charge cable that came with the dock (and bypassed the dock) to my Note II and it plugs in fine! Looking at the plugs side by side, I noticed that they look different--the female slot on the dock is a bit smaller than the female slot on the micro USB plug on the charging cable...there's the culprit: manufacturing flaw, as best that I can see. All I know is that if I try to push my phone in any harder, I was afraid that I would damage my phone. I tried to get a replacement for it thinking that it may be just a fluke, but Amazon did not provide me an option to get a replacement, only a return. Now I have to pay for return postage and also out the shipping charges I paid to have it shipped to me in the first place...Oh well...just beware folks. Sucks when a product doesn't work as advertized.

    2013-04-23: I liked it a lot at first. The phone fit very snuggly on the dock and the external battery charger worked fine. My only problem was the charger they included. The charger had some sort of problem where it would make the touch screen on my phone go completely erratic. With the with a visual screen senor I could see that with the charger my phone would register my finger touching all parts of the screen when I was just touching one part.Overall the dock was great, but the charger they supplied me made my phone useless on the dock.UPDATE:After using the dock as a charger for two weeks (while the charger did make the screen go crazy, it did however charge my phone) my phone has stopped charging.The orange light would turn on indicating that the phone was being "charging" but the battery continued to deplete.After contacting HTC and telling them my problem they concluded that my phones USB port had been fried. The HTC representative I spoke too told me this dock and its supplied charger were probably the what caused my problem and that I would have to have the phone repaired or replaced.If you get a bad charger from these guys, return it immediately, it could end up frying the USB port on your phone like it did to mine.

    Rating: 1

    2013-04-07: Seems to be working as advertised. You do have to take the phone's case off--fortunately I have a very minimal Boxwave case that comes off instantly (very handy for quick battery swaps if needed). The aux battery charging slot in the back of the EZO is a snug fit, but not a problem. No stability issues noted.Let me add an important battery tip for owners of the original Note if you think your phone isn't giving you a full days charge... I put up with what I thought was normal battery life for the Note for over a year--I thought I just had to live with it. I would take the phone off of the charger with 100% at 6:30 am, and do various light email, web & app browsing (stuff like G+, Twitter, Flipboard) plus maybe stream music for a couple of hours. By 3:30 it would frequently be at under 20%, sometimes even without much use at all. I discovered that my battery was likely improperly calibrated from the very beginning. I recently did a factory reset and then did a 'battery calib' which consists of charging to 100%, turning off & removing battery for a minute, turning back on an immediately recharging to 100% again. I now get enough charge to do all of the above things and usually have 75% left by evening. I could probably skip a day if I wanted. I liked this phone a lot before but the battery management was a bit annoying. Now I friggin' LOVE it. I will think twice about upgrading to Jelly Bean (if it ever shows up) for fear of losing this awesome performance I'm getting now.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-09: These little chargers are absolutely wonderful. Their small, inexpensive and you can get them in a lot of different colors. They are very handy when you need to charge your phone for your tablet while you're driving so though be ready when you get to your destination. They also work for your tom-tom or other device that needs a USB connection. I buy a lot of them for myself and friends and customers. Their cheap enough that you can give them away as a gift. I definitely recommend this to anyone who needs to charge a device on the run.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-25: When I first got this little guy in the mail I was pretty happy with it.As others have stated, the item received was NOT the same as the item pictured, but I actually liked that.Instead of having a silver front-facing plate like in the pic, mine was all black with a single blue LED light.It worked really great too, for a few months anyway. After that it began blowing my fuse whenever I plugged it in.Granted changing fuses in a car (I have a Jeep Wrangler, so it's under the hood) is pretty simple, but after the thirdor fourth occurrence, it becomes a bit tiresome. After I used my last spare fuse I decided to purchase a new(and different) USB charger from elsewhere. That new one has been with me longer than this one ever was,and has yet to give me a singe problem.Also, I would like to add that I did take apart this USB charger after I replaced it with the new one. I figured a contact hadcome loose inside and was shorting things out, and thus blowing my fuses. I was wrong. It seems whatever was causingmy fuses to blow was due to some failed component within the unit itself. I did not care enough to poke around with myvoltage meter to find the issue, but it does look to me that my charger has some fatal design flaw, perhaps broughtout by prolonged usage (I leave mine plugged in, so it was always on when my Jeep was running). Perhaps mine wasjust a crappy unit, but it stands to reason that others out there will likely fail in the same way. Do yourself a favor andgrab a different USB charger.~Rusty

    Rating: 1

  • B009LS142A

    $B009LS142A

    2013-06-19: Was quite excited to find this phone with Net10 service at Amazon, (Amazing Amazon!), because, the Net10 750 minute card for $25.00, gives me the biggest bang for the buck, and web/data usage is just deducted from the minutes also. I wanted as "smart" a phone as I could get without being required to pay $40.00 or more per month for service, and the LG 840G fits the bill beautifully! I must admit that I don't tend to use the web on my phone all that much, but the screen is an acceptable size if I need to do so. The camera is great and I've sent photos to friends. ( I'm not a kid, and switched from a flip phone, to see if I could adjust to the touch screen, and it was so easy with this phone!) Texting is a "piece of cake", with the virtual qwerty keyboard. The service is key, though. Tracfone is great, (same family as Net10), as this phone, as a tracfone, has triple minutes for life, but if you require 500 or more minutes per month, this phone, wit Net10 service is the way to go. I like using a stylus with it, and Amazon has some great choices, (including some that connect to the phone so it is always handy), but the touch screen responds just as well to your fingertips. The LG840G may not be a smartphone, per se, but it is certainly smart enough for me, and, probably for many more people out there, who just wanna be a bit more updated and feel more connected to what everyone else is doing.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-19: Bought my wife one a couple weeks ago and liked it so well I bought myself one.I've been using NET10 for years. This phone works off 3G. For two senior citizens, it does all we requie.Only down side is the touch screen. Being seniors it's been an ajustment for us to learn to touch softly.If you want a phone that makes calls, has a good calender to keep your appointments. This is it.It is not an internet surfing machine. It's not a smart phone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-09-05: I had bought same phone in white for myself- only difference it was tracfone. I liked it so much I bought one for boyfriend through Net 10. His phone didn't even last a month before the screen went totally blank. Was unable to reset. Sent back and got refund.

    2013-05-12: It is a good phone!     2013-03-05: Great Phone, I highly recommend. A first model one I had seemed to have an issue with the Hibernate button, but no more.     2011-05-01: We've had this product for several months now and are glad we purchased it (through Amazon). The price was right and it works as advertised. Now that my wife and I have matching phones (HTC Evo's)it's so convenient to be able to plug in either or both phones while driving. The unit comes packaged with one cord so we just bring along an extra one so we can charge both phones at the same time.Usually, my wife seems to always forget to charge her phone at home so she's used it quite a bit more than I. When we're on long road trips we leave the phones plugged in so we can use them as we travel and when we get to our distination, our phones are (usually) fully charged for a day of sight-seeing.I use the GPS (Sprint service) feature on the phone, so my old Magellan GPS is now obsolete. Besides, the battery had gone out (dead) on the Magellan and it would have cost what I paid for one of the phones (with rebate), and I was just about to pay out nearly a hundred dollars to update the navigation system. Thank goodness we bought the new phones.By the way, the blue light on the plug (the part that goes into the car's cigarette lighter) is just right and bright enough to let us know the connection is working. The phones have battery-charging indicators also.Rate a 10 on a scale of 1-10. Great product and well made.

    Rating: 5

    2012-07-17: The batteries are good, last about a day with little to no use of our Droid-Xs (bluetooth & email on, GPS off). The batteries fit well w/o use of a case extender.The charger is a different story. It is almost impossible to line up the tiny contacts with the battery terminals, especially if you have mature eyesight and arthritic hands! There is little to no friction in the contact bar making it darn near impossible to keep the battery aligned while plugging it into the outlet. Because we have 6 of the same size/type batteries, I resorted to gluing the sliding contacts to a fixed position.

This way you can use your phone with all features on (wifi, GPS, bluetooth, 4g, gaming, etc.) with no fear of running out of battery for the rest of the day.

  • B0093IHY7M

    $B0093IHY7M

    2012-12-31: I had a previous Speck case for an iPhone 4 when Apple was issuing free cases after the reception debacle a few years ago. It was the best case I have ever had. I prefer a rubberized grip case that gives a good grip, but is still relatively lightweight. Even the Apple store employees have recommended this case as a favorite and it is easy to see why. It is easy to add your phone, provides protection and some lightweight drop protection if dropped on the side or back (also pointed out by an Apple employee). There are the necessary openings for your peripherals and a covered button for the On/Off switch. The grip is great and you can charge and sync in the case with no problems! This is the only case I use for my phones. I highly recommend them.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-11: Recently upgraded from the iPhone 4 to the 5s.This case is great! The matte finish helps for the grip. The buttons for the volume and sleep/wake works and responsive. The cut outs for the head jack is nice and large. Worked with my beats pro jack. Cut out for lightning cable is perfectly fine, cannot say for third party lightning cables but its fine with the apple stock.What made me a little worried was the camera cut out. I've seen some cases with a larger cut out but my photos were clear, not washed out and the flash worked fine.There is a lay on the table design but its very subtle. I currently have a temporary screen shield and there's plenty of lay on the table design. But I'll see how it is once I've received my tempered glass screen shield.Overall great product!- Slim- Simple yet, stylish- Great grip- Decent price! (Bought at $19.99)

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-04: I upgraded to an IPhone 5 so I needed a new case. I had a similar speck case for my 4S and it did a great job protecting the phone which I regularly dropped - it survived without a scratch. Best case I've ever owned ad would highly recommended it. .

    Rating: 5

    2012-12-27: I read some of the reviews before I made the purchase, knowing that there are complaints for poor manufacturing or craftsmanship. So I thought about "well, if it doesn't pan out, I would just return it"I got it this morning "blue harbor version", and it actually fits rather well with iPhone 5. It gives you enough wiggle room to fit the device inside the case without scratching the edges. Once it is inside, it feels fit, and device doesn't move around as far as I can tell. The case, even though it is rubberized, is actually quite rigid plastic (only the little matte squares are somewhat rubberized).The only complaint I have so far with this phone is that some people (not everyone) complain that they can't seem to hear me all that well. Looking closely at the case, Speck tries its best to fit all the individual mic/speaker openings to the actual openings on iPhone 5. However, if the device moves a little bit to the right or left inside the case (not noticeable from pure visual inspection), I suppose those openings can get obstructed. Another theory to the voice quality drop is entirely unrelated to the case itself. I have heard report on drops in voice quality via LTE, so I need to verify if voice quality does improve if I disable LTE.And I am in Houston, TX, where LTE band 17 is operated.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-21: This tough low profile case is a steal at under $20, out performing much more expensive cases with ease. The phone feels very secure and protected in the tight, form fitting PixelSkin HD unlike it's lazy step-brother, the regular PixelSkin. My only wish is that it had more of a rubberized TPU feel. The back and sides end up feeling much more plastic and slippery and don't lend to a very good grip. Still, all in all a very good pick for price, the PixelSkin HD is sure to provide style and durability in a cost effective package.Enjoy!

It's pretty sturdy, fits perfect, and adds the valuable protection i need for my phone. If you are clumsy, I'd recommend a more sturdy cover. This cover is good for light drops and bumps.

    2013-06-20: I've had about 3-4 speck cases for my iphone 4 and 4's in addition to the two I had for my ipad. I've always been pleased because speck generally learned from the cases they made and improved. Not the case with the iphone 5. The case is too firm compared to the material used to produce the 4/4s case. The buttons are the side are stiff as was the power button. It did not feel like the phone was protected well at all and I've felt like if I dropped the phone it would fall out. I am writing this review a little late as I had the case back in November, and it is now June. Speck may have made changes and that is great, but buyer beware for when the case you receive was made.

The lock and volume buttons are easy to press mushy affect to them at all. I have a screen protecter on both the front and back of the phone and let me tell you that you don't Have to worry about it peeling of getting messed up. I must say that I wanted a nice sleek compact case and that's what I got. This was a big step away from all the bulky cases I have purchased in the past. I 100% recommend this case for anyone who is looking for a simple case. Thank you very much

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-22: Purchased this because of the reviews and the looks of the case. It offers excellent protection to the Xperia Z. All sides of the phone are protected and the corners are thicker to protect against corner falls. All buttons are accessible. The charging and audio ports are a little bit difficult to uncover, but not impossible. The edges around the screen of the phone tend to collect quite a bit of dirt, which might scratch your screen or screen protector. This case is meant to be carried in your pocket or purse. A belt clip would've been nice. Instead you get a kick stand. The kick stand's design is good, but the method of it clicking closed is kind of poor. It relies on two small plastic teeth to snap into the body of the case. However, frequent use of the kick stand will make those teeth go dull and eventually wont snap on the case anymore. Overall, good case.

    Rating: 4

    2013-08-24: Very few choices in the market for Xperia Z cases. This one fits the bill and is economical. Had difficulty putting it on over the edges as the case is perfect and tight.. as one user mentioned - possibility of scratching . Found a simple work-around.1. Pull out the soft gel case from the hard case (they are two separate pieces)2. First pull only the gel case on the phone.3. Slip on the hard case easily - over the gel - Bingo

    2013-05-25: I was a bit hesitant to buy this case because I generally prefer fully TPU cases. Every other color of this case had near perfect rating. So, I figured why not give this case a shot? It ended up being a great choice. This case is actually partial-TPU, it wraps around the sides of the phone like a bumper. Yet, it has a hardshell backing that joins it. I found the design of the case really creative and the color is great, it's a bright enough color that it makes finding my phone easy. The case also adds practically no bulk to the phone and fits it snugly. I would highly recommend this case to anyone searching for a new case!

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-21: Received this case yesterday and have been using it since.For the price, this is a pretty good case.Pros:-Hard plastic on the back provides good scratch protection.-The TPU material of the bumper actually protrudes a little from the front of the phone when in use, allowing you to put your phone face down and not worry about scratching the front-TPU material is soft and malleable enough that it's quite easy to operate the covered power and volume buttons, and also easy to operate the mute toggle switch-Price is greatCons:-Charging port cut-out will only accommodate the default Apple Lightning charger. Any kind of aftermarket charger will simply not fit-Even worse, the cutout for headphones won't fit ANY headphones or any other kind of 3.5mm cable I tried to put in there, including my specially-designed-for-this-kind-of-thing Mediabridge 3.5mm cable.However, the price is good enough that these cons are somewhat forgivable. The case is easy enough to remove that you can plug in what you need. If I were to pay anymore than the $5.95 they're asking though, I would expect the manufacturer to address this issue.Would be nice though if most case designers realized that consumers don't want to have to remove their case anytime they want to charge the phone or use the headphone jack.

    Rating: 3

  • B007MC6WGK

    $B007MC6WGK

    2012-06-20: Pairing and charging were easy enough, but I am not sure I would recommend these if your primary use will be listening to music. The sound volume seems almost muffled - as another review pointed out, it seems difficult to get any sound output from these regardless of my device's volume setting. The sound quality itself is also very flat and hollow. The headset includes three different size earbud adapters so you can find the best fit for your ear canal. No problem there, I found a size that fits my ears just fine. But with ear buds such as this, once you insert them far enough into the ear canals you generally have quality sound and deep bass. That was not my experience with this headset - the sound was very dull and lifeless compared to my other ear buds. The quality is fine for calls, but perhaps the electronics are optimized for voice, not music. I love bluetooth earbuds because unleashed is the way to go, and the range of these is quite good. Voice use: A; music: C-

    Rating: 3

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-19: I tried to like this headset, I really did. I listen to audio books on my way to and from work so need a good headset that I can wear and be able to move my head freely without having to readjust the earbuds or having the earbuds popping out of my ears all the time. These were not that set. I tried each of the provided sets of earbuds and none of them would conform to my ears well enough that I wasn't having to constantly adjust or put them back in my ears after they popped out. I would have been really frustrated if I was to use them while I was doing any kind of vigorous movement. I gave these a three because the sound was really good and I liked the ease with which I was able to link with my phone. I was ready to go with in five minutes of taking them out of the box. Maybe it is just the shape of my ears but I haven't had this bad a problem with any other earbuds that I have used before.

    Rating: 3

    2012-07-23: I have, for a very long time, wanted a wireless earbud set. They are extremely useful, versatile, and convenient, especially when you're active. When I had the chance to try out this Plantronics BackBeat Bluetooth headset, I jumped at the opportunity.Unfortunately, I was hugely disappointed.Plantronics has always been one of the middle-of-the-road electronics company for me, never rising above some of the greats (like Bose or Sony). This set doesn't even reach mediocre.The biggest problem it has is really quite simple: Sometimes it just doesn't work. Unless my iPhone 4 is perfectly still and within a few feet of the headset, the sound flickers in & out. This is a real pain while jogging/running/working out because the motion of the iPhone sometimes interferes with the listening. The only time I've been able to have good sound quality with no flickering/interference is while sitting/standing perfectly still with the iPhone not moving. If this is the main function for the earbuds, why have them wireless? Mobility is the main reason to get wireless anything, right?Also, and this is goes right with the previous point, the range is a complete lie. The manual says the range for good quality is about 30 feet. Fully charged, properly set up with my iPhone, I maxed out around 10 feet. That's nothing. That's, what, half the length of a typical bedroom?Overall, this is NOT a good earbud system. I believe there will be good updates to it that will make it good eventually, but just avoid it for now.2/5.

    2013-08-24: Love this headset noise canceling is great sound is crisp very lightweight & portable controls are easy to use great item

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-24: My favorite bluetooth stereo headset used to be theLG Tone - HBS-700 Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange. I like these better.Outstanding sound: Great range, excellent clarity, and the supplied earbuds block out external noise.Well designed controls: The buttons, there are four, are all in one place. They are easy to press and you know when they have been... pressed.Excellent iPhone integration: The volume control on the headset controls the iPhone volume and you get an on-screen display of headset battery level. Of course pause, play, and answer/disconnect calls works. Voice commands also function flawlessly. (Or as flawlessly and the current beta version of Siri ever does which is never as good as they show on the TV commercials. But, I digress...)Convenient: You can stuff them in any convenient pocket when not in use. Or, if you want to show them some love, they fit perfectly in aCosmos Black bluetooth handsfree headset HARD EVA Case - Clamshell/MESH Style with Zipper Enclosure, Inner Pocket, and Durable Exterior for Aliph Jawbone 2, Aliph Jawbone Prime, Jabra BT804+ Cosmos cable tie(or any of the other identical offerings on Amazon.The cord: The cord is a great length. It's longer enough so the earbuds don't snag when they're in you rears and so they hang down at a reasonable level when they're not. That is, in case you're wondering, 25". It's flat, as opposed to round, and doesn't slide on skin. The benefit is the buds won't slide off when they're not in your ears. (Thanks to the aforementioned length they still don't pull when you're listening to music.)Multiple device support: Not there and not a problem if you only need to connect to one device. If it is a problem the check out the LG Tone I mentioned up top. Ir is a pretty good headset and you might even find a used one on eBay before very long...

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-30: I bought this from Fry's on sale for $59.00 (normal retail price $99.00). Surprisingly, this BT headset sound quality ain't bad! It's crisp and clean with a good mix of low bass. Granted the sound is far from my Sony BT50 or X10, but for $59.00 it's a good value Streaming music from my iPhone worked well. Once paired, you'll see a small battery meter in the upper right corner. My primary use of this headphones was for gym (I also have a Sony BT50 but at times, find this a bit too big). Since I primarily use it on my iPhone, I didn't matter if it was not able to multi-pair.Likes:- Micro USB charger- Small size- Sound Quality. Overall good sound- Cord length. It's about 18-inches, and I think it's a good length.- Includes a couple of extra loop for a more comfortable stay in ear fit.Neutral:- Battery life rated at 4.5 hours of usage, and it's pretty dead on. Given it's size, I think this is acceptable but would've like the usage to be in the 6 hour range- Noise Isolation. Compared to my X10, this does not isolate noise that well.Dislikes:- Switching out tips can be a tough. During my fitting, I was afraid I was going to rip the tips. There were no instructions included on how to properly switch them out.- Volume. Volume not very high. I estimate it's about 75% of my x10- Remote. Hard to see and press. Although it's raised buttons, it's mono-black and hard to see and feel the right button. The remote also has not dedicated buttons to skip tracks.- No case/pouch to carry this in...Overall, I give this 5 starts because of it's value vs. price..

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 3

    2012-05-24: This two-earplug Bluetooth headset supports both phone profiles and stereo audio profiles, so it works as both a phone headset and stereo earphones for music. Like pretty much all Bluetooth headsets on the market today, it has just one tiny LED (dual-color, red and blue) and a few small buttons, so remember what the LED indicator represents and which button does what is a royal pain, especially for an old chap like myself. (I own five BT headsets each with its own indicator interpretations and one-press/two-press functions.)The first thing you may notice is the user-unfriendly packaging. It's not as evil as plastic clamshells but it features plenty of invisible clear tape so you'll get frustrated when you discover there's one more tape you haven't removed. Getting the headphones out of the setting clips should be done with care or you can damage the headphones. The tiny booklet included does not make learning any easier, but it's soemthing you should not leave home without, because you'll need it to learn how to interpret the LED status and also which button is for what, as mentioned before.My biggest beef is the ear plugs are of a very poor fit for me, and I've tried all four sets included in the box. I'm used to invasive earplugs like these but this is the first set that truly manages to make me feel uncomfortable. The end of the plug comes out way too much and makes me look like the Count from Sesame Street, especially if I go out with my beloved cape. The mediocre sound quality does not save this model.In short, this is a rather poor product.

    2013-01-12: If you are a casual user who needs these for an hour at a time at the gym or for a conference call then these MIGHT suffice. I say might because the volume level is so low that any significant background noise will drown out the audio. Battery life is terrible.. you will be lucky to get 3 full hours out of them on a full charge. Do not plan on using these if you are mowing the lawn or using loud equipment, you will not be able to hear the audio. You can't pair with more than one device at a time so be prepared to fumble around and turn off blue tooth on one device just to get the headphones to repair with another device. This has been a big inconvenience. Positives are that they are light, fit well in the ear and are very inconspicuous. I would not recommend these to anyone and will be buying the bluebuds x when available on Amazon.

    2012-12-05: I own four pairs of bluetooth stereo in ear headphones and none have the quality sound these have. Out of the box, the mid size plugs were too large, once fitted with the smaller size, which are perfect for me, the base came alive. The sound quality is ridiculously owesome for a sub sixty bucks pair of headphones.I paired it with my iphone, laptop, ipad, new Galaxy Note 2 and have no problems switching back and forth with all these devices. I just have to turn off the headphones and depending on the proximity to my other devices, turn off the bluetooth on the ones I don't want to sink with at the time.I also downloaded a player app with sound equalizer to enhance the volume since these don't have a loud volume and now with that app, I'm all set, plus I get a more enhanced sound quality, not that I needed it since the earphones sound awesome already. The highs are crisp, the mids are just well balanced and the lows are nice deep and clean.I never thought I'd get this level of sound quality from a "phone" products company, but Plantronics has done a great job with these.If I break these, I will run to get another set.I doubt these would be ideal for working out since there is no loop hook to secure, but that's not what I bought them for. Besides, these will prevent outside sound to penetrate and will isolate you from the outside noise, which you don't want when you are doing outdoor activities or working out, but they will be ideal for a plane ride or at night when you want to listen in bed.

    2012-07-16: I had the chance to try out these Backbeat headphones and I am not that happy with them. The bluetooth range is about 10 or so feet (I'm ball-parking it, I have been able to leave my phone in my room and go the the second floor of my home and still hear music).Would I buy again?     2012-06-02: there is a hilarious market to follow in how earphone producers try to develop methods in how to keep earphones stable in the ear. not sure if anything is as laughable as what the plantronics set do, given 100 different attempts to put them on, you will actually have 100 different fits.beyond that, standard fair, average audio quality, lightweight but not sweatproof rated so pointless there. in general, becoming sweatproof or waterproof rated means you take a serious audio quality hit. so with this being not rated for that, it's audio should kill the comp but in practice it's very very average. the jaybird jf3's blow these away from an audio standpoint. they last longer too, they are sweatproof too....these are a good set of bluetooth stereo sets to have, but that said, your money can buy better.

I tried switching the earbuds, but larger was too large and smaller was no help at all. If they fit you, I think you will probably like them, but there's no way to tell up front.

    Rating: 4

    2012-08-24: The Plantronics BackBeat GO wireless earbuds offer the ability to connect to your phone or player through a Bluetooth connection to avoid the annoyance of a cord running between the earbuds and the music source. The wireless connectivity is a big advantage over wired headphones in my opinion and I own several Bluetooth earbuds for running. However, I found that I was disappointed with the Plantronics BackBeat GO.The headset comes with instructions which detail how to pair the headsets with your devices, how to decipher the beeps that occur if you are on hold and the buttons. Pairing was very easy. There are chimes that play when you turn the headphones on and off which is a nice feature so that you know to release the on button. However, the little indicator light on one of the headsets is impossible to find when it is not lit and so you need to be looking at both earbuds when you first pair to be able to find it.Personally, I was not a big fan of the fit of the headsets. The earbuds come with three additional eartips to allow for a good fit. There is also a stabilizer which can be added. The instructions read that you are supposed to be able to put the rubber loop of the stabilizer into the area of your ear. However, no matter which eartips you use, the earbuds do not register on your outer ear and so I found that they were not very stable no matter which eartips I used. Moving my head would cause the earbuds to dislodge. Even when in place, the earbuds were not very comfortable. I would never wear them running, for example since they would become dislodged very quickly.The controls for the earbuds are located on the cord that runs between them. I would have preferred that the controls were on one of the headsets. The location of the controls puts them somewhere on the back of your neck when you have the earbuds in place. Therefore, you have to feel around to find the controls. You must do this blindly and at first it is just easier to take the headset off. But, with time, you learn to figure out where the buttons are located by touch.The sound quality from the earbuds is disappointing. I also found the earbuds to be disappointing when trying to make a phone call. The person that I was speaking with complained about the clarity of my voice. I disconnected and then paired with another set of Bluetooth earbuds and that time the person could hear me clearly. Therefore, the problem was with the Plantronics earbuds.Overall, I would not recommend the Plantronics BackBeat GO wireless earbuds. They are not comfortable to wear, the controls are awkward and the sound quality is poor. Better options for Bluetooth headphones are available. I would recommend considering theMotorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Blackwhich have far superior sound quality, fit and function than the Plantronics.

    Rating: 2

    2013-05-04: If you're looking for a tangle free, sporty, and hassle free headset than this is the one for you!     2013-05-24: Just a tip... ignore the one star comments from people saying it's horrible, terrible, don't buy. Notice they never say what stereo bluetooth product is actually "great" in comparison. That's because have never used a stereo bluetooth headset before with noise cancelling before. This product is pretty-much as good as it gets if you want hands-free noise-cancelling stereo bluetooth headphones.Note: All noise cancelling bluetooth headsets are inherently going to be low volume. Higher volumes would cause noise cancelling to not work correctly; hence, the limitation on volume amplification.If your ears are sensitive to loud sound, I doubt you're going to find a bluetooth stereo headset earbuds better than this.

    2012-04-17: I have searched far n wide to find the best portable headset but could not find one, until I saw this one. It is just perfect design and best portable bluetooth headset yet.1. Sound quality.Though it is not the best of the quality, but the quality is not depended on the headset alone, Same mp3 file played on different phones sound different. This is because the way the bluetooth stack is written for those devices. I tested it with several devices, the best I found was with HTC EVO and worst was iPhone 4. But still it is not all that bad.2. Wired headset vs bluetooth headset.Wired headset and bluethooth headsets are just different, it is like comparing apple (wired) and oranges(bluetooth) but both are fruits (headsets). Wired headset does not have to worry about the power, while the bluetooth headsets need to check the battery level to get that 4.5 hrs battery life.3. Battery Life.Right on the dot, 4.5 hrs, period.4.     Rating: 5

    2012-05-30: I love the design on these - that they link together behind the head, and you can easily control volume and phone answering with a little set of buttons that hang near your neck. There are three bud sizes, and they fit nicely in my ears and stay there even when I'm running. I know others have complained about the fit, but for me they've been fine.The sound is a bit more muddy than other earphones I've tried, even much less expensive plug-in earphones. As others have noted, the bass quality is also very weak. So I'd say these are not the best choice for the audiophile, and not the best choice if your primary purpose is to listen to music cord free. On the other hand, they do sound well enough, and so if your main aim is hands-free calling, and you only listen to music every once in a while, these wouldn't be a bad way to go. They work fine for calls, but perhaps the mike input is a bit low for receivers on the other end.I have noticed that they seem to stutter and drop Bluetooth signal a bit more frequently than other Bluetooth-enabled devices I've tried. That has happened both with my phone and with my computer (note that unlike many other Bluetooth devices I've tried these can only be "paired" to one device at a time - so they wouldn't be useful if you wanted to pair them to your phone on a commute and then to your computer once you got to work).Overall, these are not bad, but I've tried better (likethisone that doesn't look as good as these but sounds and performs better at a lower cost; orthisone that sounds and performs quite a bit better but at a higher cost). The deal breaker for me is that the signal seems to cut out for a moment every so often. I've had that happen every once in a random while with almost every Bluetooth device I've owned, but with this one it seems to be pretty regular.

    2012-06-18: I really like this wireless headset.     Rating: 1

    2012-10-18: My scenario: I had always been wanting a BT headset for my iphone. Figured it would be convenient, but I just kept using the included wired buds because I was being too lazy to shop and order, plus too cheap to purchase to replace something that was working. Then my wife decided to help out: she broke my included iphone earbuds, and I figured that if I was going to get a new pair of headphones/whatever, now would be the time to research and get what I wanted.I had a basic idea of it: a BT headset that would be small and indiscrete, have decent sound quality, and as a bonus I'd LOVE to find one that let me listen to music. Why not, I was shopping for myself and hell that way I wouldn't have to juggle a headset/stereo headphones depending on the situation.I started my online research not knowing what I would find, I hadn't looked in this direction in almost a decade, and didn't even know if what I wanted existed. To my surprise there were TONS of BT stereo sets that also took calls. YAY! Only problem was that they were definitely too bulky for my tastes; I wanted something pocketable and discrete and easy to carry around without being inconvenient. Then I found these guys. I was intrigued because they were comparatively TINY, basically just regular wired earbuds without, you know, THE WIRE, so they'd stow really well. They were also really well rated at other dedicated electronics sites, so I started shopping.I was concerned about two things I kept reading: lack of volume, and ease of pairing/ease of use. Still I decided to try them as there were also a lot of positive reviews.For the first day or so I was very pleased with them. However by the 3rd day I was a little less enthusiastic. I wasn't sure if they were THAT convenient, more so than just a regular, small BT headset with boom mic, and worth the tradeoffs. I was THIS close to sending them back. But I decided to hold out just a little longer and not THINK about it so much, just use it. And I'm glad I did.YES, the volume is a little lower than I would have liked. Basically on my iphone I have to have the volume slider at least 25% up to hear a damned thing. It does get louder quicker from there, but still not as loud as I would like. However this seems to be limited to the music only. On phone calls, volume is just fine. And since these are ear-sealing earbuds, my fears that ambient noise would drown out the device even at full volume were unfounded -- basically, the upper limits of the volume are just fine, as they do such a good job of sealing out unwanted noise from your surroundings, that it just about balances out.As far as the convenience factor... they pull out quickly and tangles are not an issue; as long as you can grab the bud and place it in your ear, the controls are right there to turn on/answer calls, so in all actuality they're just as convenient as an ordinary boom mic unit. For me I use the largest tips inlcuded, as I find this allows for a little better bass response. Took some getting used to, but if you give it a bit of time to to get adjusted and figure out what placement works best for you, it becomes much less of a chore and quicker and easier within a couple of days of use.Bottom line: They're a bit quieter than the wired iphone earbuds I replaced them with, they're maybe slightly less convenient than a regular BT headset to pull out and put to use, BUT: the convergence factor is AWESOME. they're LOUD ENOUGH, they are damned near as convenient if not identically so to using a regular BT boom mic, and as a plus you can also listen to music in stereo? Very little tradeoff, very much gained as far as I am concerned.

    Rating: 4

    2012-07-03: I have been using this headset with my Toshiba Thrive Tablet, and while I can't bring myself to rave about them due to some frustrating issues, there are some good points.Likes:- Decent sound when turned up on the headset itself (more on this in the Dislikes section below)- The noise-cancelling technology works well - almost too well (also more on this below)- Comfortable - my ears do not get sore inside after longer uses- The connecting wire is just long enough and doesn't kink up- The battery life is decent- I've never had a Bluetooth stereo headset before, and now I'm hooked on being able to move away from my tablet while watching video or listening to music with the headset! More fun while cooking, cleaning, etc.!- The small spot for plugging in the charger is cleverly hidden on one of the earbudsDislikes:- When I turn the volume up on my device instead of the headset, I find the sound quality becomes thin, losing the lower decibels. I have to keep the tablet volume turned as low as possible, and then only adjust the volume on the headset to avoid this issue.- I have to use the largest set of tips plus the stablizers, and these still don't stay in my ears well. I push them in as far as possible, and figured out the inside-ear stablizers after some trial-and-error, but the soft, supple nature of the tips allows them to keep slipping out. The only thing that ever seems to keep earbuds in my ears is small, comfortable hooks over the outside of the ear. I guess I have large ear canals or something! Unfortunately, hooks are not part of the options kit that comes with this particular headset.- I generally feel like I have my fingers plugging my ears when I'm wearing these. Go ahead - plug your ears for a minute, and do some normal stuff, like chew, walk, and talk. The way the sounds of those activities are amplified in my head while plugging my ears is the same as when wearing these earbuds. Also, if something taps the wire (like an earring or my shirt collar), the sound is magnified greatly.- This plugged-ear sensation also makes it difficult to hear someone who walks up to talk to me - I either have to turn off the music/video (turning it down is not enough, even at the lowest level it's still difficult to hear someone else), or I have to take out one or both of the buds completely.I have found a lot of uses for this headset, and do enjoy being able to listen to my things without disturbing those around me. However, I get frustrated by the earbuds sliding out of my ears, even when sitting still, and the plugged-ear-amplification issue is very distracting.

    Rating: 3

    2012-07-26: Ditto others comments. Ultimate convenience. Useful for exercise and running like wired earbuds. But low base response unless really pushed deeply into your ear (which does not stay). Helps to adjust equalizer on your phone, if available, for stereo music playing. Talk AND Stereo bluetooth playing time is 3 hrs max. Tried to use it on cross-continent flight for movie viewing on a tablet but lost power into third hour. With volume on tablet/phone and unit at max, can barely hear in some situations (plane, walking, etc). So tiny unit with tiny battery gives you less usable time and lower volume to get the time it gives, it seems.

    Rating: 3

    2013-07-16: I love this headset. It is the best bluetooth I have ever used and pretty much the only one which is loud enough and blocks out all the sound so I can talk to anybody on the phone. It's also really good for music which I wasn't looking for but is a large added bonus!Be warned however that (and I guess it's depending on which ear peices you choose) this will "seal" up your ear and it's a little odd when you're using them, but you could be standing next to a lawnmower and you'd still be able to hear. It takes a little getting used to, but I absolutly like it.

    2012-07-27: This headset has all the advantages of a wireless model, with very few disadvantages. It is small, lightweight, good fit, and has integrated call controls. The sound quality is very good, and the range is farther than wired versions.The only disadvantage I can see is that they need to be charged up, and they have to be turned off and on to use.     Rating: 5

    2013-11-10: I got these a while ago, but still use the heck out of them. They are small, and I paired them with the Comply Foam Ear Buds, and that really helps block out the extra noise.     Rating: 5

    2012-06-27: One of my eternal complaints about BT headphones is that the reception is always lousy. Once I walk outside I might as well just remove my headphones because the sound cuts out so often that the music is not enjoyable. Luckily, THESE PLANTRONICS HEADPHONES HAVE GREAT RECEPTION. I am so happy. I previously tried the Jabra SPORT and Motorola SF600. Both had a few merits but terrible reception.Plantronics:Pros:Reception: Excellent reception (I know I keep going on about this but it's a really big deal to me and they excel). I really don't think I've had these cut out on me once when they're within 10-15 feet of my phone.Controls: The controls are on the cord which I really like. With the other headphones the controls are located on the actual units instead of the cord. Because of this I always felt like I was pushing my ear around when I reached for buttons. With the controls on the cord this is not an issue.Cord Length: Some reviewers have mentioned that they think it is too long but I think it's just right. The cord is long enough that it doesn't rub my neck all the time. Also, when I remove the buds from my ears I can just drape the cable over my neck so they're available quickly when I want to wear them again.Pairing: As with any BT device these pair easily the first time. However, they also seem well programmed and pair with devices after that too. Seems obvious but not every BT headset is so streamlined.Cons:Sound Quality: This is tough because the reception somewhat makes up for this. However, the plain truth is that the sound quality is only so-so. The bass is definitely lacking (and I'm not a pure basshead). The trebles and midrange are pretty nice. Personally, I like the sound of the Motorola models better but would still choose Plantronics for reception reasons. For a comparison, my daily headphones are Ultimate Ears SuperFi 5 Pros. It's not a fair to compare these two but I do care about music quality.Battery Life: Acceptable but not excellent. I generally get a couple of solid hours out of them but nowhere near the 4 hours that they advertise.Fit: If you're sitting in one room not moving much then the fit is pretty decent. However, if you are outside moving around a lot then these can pretty easily get jarred from your ears. I'm seriously considering making some foam buds to replace the silicon that come from the factory.Final verdict: Pretty good compared to the competition that I've tried. If the bass response/sound quality and fit were better I'd easily give 5 stars. As is, they earn a very solid 4.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-13: Light and easy to use. Sound it pretty good. Sounds like any other in ear headphone I have owned. You still can't replace the over the ear type for best sound quality though.

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-20: I tried the behind the neck hard headphones. They were terrible. I haven't really tested the length of power that I get, but I have them on for at least 2 1/2 hour when I work out and on the way home and to the gym. I have sat my phone down at the gym and walked to get some weights, range was at least 10 feet and connection never failed!!! VERY VERY happy that I paid for these

    2013-08-11: After 3 months of intensive use of the device I can now say that the product is not bad at all. I found the sound quality not bad or I should say very good. What I like about these is that they are discreet (some people did not even notice it was around my neck at times, I can walk at night in peace not having the fear of attracting attention with a flashing blue light) and I can sleep with them. No with the tear and wears of the past months the stabilisers are good for nothing. They do not help anymore. Another thing I do not like is the fact that battery life kept on decreasing as the months passed by. Brand new was like 2,5-3 hours of audio and 4 hours stand by. Now it is much less like an 1-2 hours audio and 2.5-3 hours stand by. So I would say that the battery life is another negative point and this lead to a drop of 1 additional star because the earbuds are small so it is expected that the battery life would not be that great but the fact they did not allow us to charge on laptops and obliged to always carry around the charger and find a charging outlet which is of great inconvenience if you commuting.lastly ending this review with a positive point is that the product wire does not get tangled. Well yes if you don't mind taking into consideration these negative points.

    2013-07-30: I'm very pleased with my Case Star tripod. I got it for holding my Droid Razr phone, and it does a good job of it. The range of sizes the clip will hold are a bit broader than stated in the specifications for the large (L): I measure 2.25 inches up to just over 3.5 inches. I'm guessing that Case's other sizes are similarly understated, so I probably could have gotten one with a smaller clip, but this works great.The legs are easy to bend and straighten, and the feet have a slightly rubbery feel that gives them some grip. The contact points of the clip are also rubbery so that they securely hold your phone without scratching it. By adjusting the feet, I can shoot at a very steep downward angle without toppling the tripod.My only complaint is that the clip has some wobble to it where it screws onto the base, even when it is screwed in all the way (it feels like the threads are stripped). This makes the phone bounce when I touch it, but because of the shutter delay, there doesn't seem to be any effect on photos or videos.Overall, I'm very pleased with this tripod, and I wish I'd bought one sooner.

    2010-10-06: As another reviewer mentioned, the iphone adapter becomes stressed and breaks over time. Mine lasted about 6 months, and I'm very gentle with my electronics.     Rating: 3

    2009-04-19: I find the that Callpod Chargepod adaptor for the iPod and iPhone fits in my iPod a little bit tighter than the charger that came with the iPod...maybe a little too tight. Yet it charges the iPod without any problems. In my opinion Callpod should have included this accessory with the callpod chargepod. I was frustrated that I had to purchase it, but very happy with it's function.I love the callpod chargepod, which is a round hub with 6 "spokes" of chargers sticking out of it. I have not found a single one my my rechargable electronics for which there is no callpod adapter. I felt that the default adapter's included with the callpod were not the best choice. So before purchasing a callpod make sure you count the cost of all of the spokes that you will purchase; they usually will cost you between seven and ten bucks apiece. But for me that is worth it.My life is a tangle of cords and the callpod chargepod works to fix that. I keep my six devices (usually two blackberries, an ipod, two bluetooth headsets, and an Amazon Kindle) charging in a self-contained circle without cords going everywhere and without the use of a powerstrip. Then when I travel, I can connect those same device to the car charger using the car power adapter. And in a hotel room, I can charge all my devices (including any that charge via usb using the usb adapter) without bringing tons of cords. The callpod is an expensive, yet for many, worthwhile accessory for your portable electronics.

    2014-06-23: The iOttie is the best car mount I've ever used (I've had about four) and only $25 it's a great deal.One thing I love about this mount are the fact that is such a quick release for your phone. You just hit the two buttons on the side and your phone is instantly released. And then when you want to mount your phone you just press it into the cradle and it snaps closed. It's the best design I've ever seen on any mount.Another thing is the suction cup. Most vehicle mounts that have a suction cup are only designed for the window. And if you can avoid the bumps in the road eventually it's been a falloff. But the iOttie is something else there gel-based suction cup works amazingly well. Even on dashboards which kind of blew my mind that it works so well. And it's just nice because it gives you more options over securing it to your window. Mine hasn't fallen off in over a week.The last thing I like is the reach of the unit. You can really get your phone close to you because the arm is so long. But it can also be pushed in if you want to have a further away. It's a really nice design.This is going to be the dock I recommend to my friends/family/customers from here on out.     2014-07-09: Since I use my Motorola Droid HD phone for GPS navigation, having a reliable way to hold the phone in a plainly visible horizontal position in my motorhome is important. Sticking the base of this holder onto a side window, extending the holder to its maximum length and positioning the holder horizontally puts my phone at the right height to view while driving yet not be in the way.Pressing my phone into the holder causes the grippers on this holder to automatically snap and secure my phone. Squeezing the release buttons allows the phone to fall into my hand. The ease with which I can secure and remove my phone does not distract from my driving.Sometimes the strong grippers will press the volume control on the side of my phone and shut down the audio, but a minor adjustment of the phone's position resolves that problem. This is by far the most useful and versatile phone holder I have used.A sample was provided to me in exchange for an honest review, which you have just read.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-28: Last year, I bought an older model of the iOttie One Touch mount and it's been working well. I was recently sent a sample of this newer model, and it's quite an improvement. Both models have a super sticky gel pad, and the one I've been using all these months has never budged from where it's mounted. It was a good solution for one of my vehicles, but I was waiting for something better to come along for another vehicle.This mount offers several improvements that make it better suited to my needs. For starters, both satisfy a basic need in that they can mount to a dashboard on a textured surface with an irregular shape. Not only does that put devices in a more convenient position, it also puts it in a legal one. In my state it's not legal to stick it to a windshield. This model has an extension so that I can move a device several inches forward, and even place the device below dashboard level with the mount on the dashboard. The range of motion is very large.The cradle itself is easy to use with one hand. Placing a device on it causes the arms to snap in place, and a one handed squeeze releases it. Unlike many I've used in the past, there's no chance of the mount or cradle coming off by accident when a device is removed.For me, the only negative is that the base doesn't swivel. It makes it harder to place the mount so that the device can be pivoted from the driver to the passenger and back. After my initial positioning, I had to remove it and mount it with the lightest of pressure until I was able to go through all the adjustments and assure they were optimal for me. Then I was able to press the tab into the second position and secure the device. It's not trivial to remove the device, nor is it a chore or anything that will damage your dashboard. It left no sticky residue. But it's not something you'd want to do each time you want to make an adjustment. Fortunately, mounting it a single time should give enough room for adjustment for just about any driver. But for a large SUV or even a minivan, your passenger might prefer to use a device in hand and then return it to the cradle.

    Rating: 4

Since this battery is listed as OEM, I expected it to be identical to the one that came with my phone. Not sure if there's much of a quality difference between the original and this one, as both seem to hold a similar amount of charge. I've been using it for a couple of months with no problems so far.For the price, the battery is fine. It holds a much better charge than a third party generic battery I purchased.

    2011-06-07: Let me first start off by reviewing this battery. In my Samsung Captivate with Serendipity 7 custom rom installed I have plenty of widgets but the battery will last a full day plus some. Since i have had my phone for around 5 months, the battery now last around 10 hours. So I am replacing my old battery (i currently have two, a new one and one that came with a Samsung charger stand I purchased) that originally came with my phone.Like another reviewer stated, I received a EB575152VU instead of a EB575152VA. It was packaged in a plastic bag, and it had a newer date on the battery (May 2011). The battery looked like a real samsung battery, just the wrong model number. The battery's white water damage indicator was showing xxxxx across the top indicating that the battery was damaged due to water. However i figured that it was re-manufactured so I tried out the battery and it does work on my captivate, however the battery will not charge through the phone! the phone will shutoff if you even try to charge it. Since i can't charge it, ended up returning the battery.My order was through Alpha INC. who has recently changed their names to Emerald LLC. It was fulfilled through Amazon so please do NOT buy from Alpha or Emerald! Amazon of course was helpful in getting a refund. Their advice for finding a real samsung battery was to try out another seller... lol. I ended up just getting this off ebay, but these batteries are only $30 from Samsung's official store.Conclusion: Be careful who you order from, and make sure it is NOT Alpha INC. or Emerald LLC. Good luck!

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-24: The product came to me late, had some charge on it . Charged but it easily goes down with talk time

    Rating: 3

    2011-06-27: Samsung Epic 4G SPH-D700 Captivate i897 i9000 Galaxy Vibrant T959 Focus I917 Cetus EB575152VA BSTD Li-Ion OEM Cell Phone Battery (1500 mAh)this is not the item you will recieve if you order this product. the item number in the description & picture is accurate but the seller i ordered from does not ship this item out. they <majicmobile>(along with numerous other sellers on amazon & ebay) are shipping a similar, cheaper battery that is a different part number and is known for having reliability issues. you want the battery with the "a" at the end, not a "u" in the part number. also notice in the picture the battery has "g9" (wich is original manufacturer), yet the one shipped is "g7". this is the HK version with a samsung sticker on it. it is NOT an OEM Samsung Vibrant (along with other models) battery. it fits but performs terribly & does not last long. its an honest shame this practice has moved to amazon.com, as its very common on ebay. please research your items, be sure your getting exactly what you order! youll find the shipping is higher than the actual item price so when you return it you end up loosing the larger portion of your cost making the return an unfortunate loss of you hard earned money!
