    2010-12-06: I ordered this product after lots of research, but still without expecting much in the way of it actually working. I had just disconnected my home phone and moved it to a cell phone in order to keep the number and save money. It was frustrating not being able to always hear the phone and I didn't want to keep moving it all the time. Got the XLink, which is way smaller than I thought it was going to be - thankfully. Plugged it in, got my cell phone to sync with the unit. It works FABULOUS! All my cordless phones throughout the house work perfectly. No interference or static. Incredible product and so thrilled that I ordered it. Now I have the best of both worlds - a lower phone bill AND house phones. Definitely recommend this product to everyone.

    Rating: 5

    2009-10-05: I've had the Xlink Bluetooth Gateway for over a month now. I had been eyeing it since I heard about it on a tech show. I finally decided to take the leap since my wife and I bought our house a year ago and I can't hear my cell phone ringing when I put it in another room or more commonly, forget to turn the ringer back on after coming home from work. My wife has had to reach me about important, time-sensitive matters numerous times and I checked my phone hours later to find I had missed about 10 calls from her. The device connects to up to 3 different phones at once, but since it is only my wife and I, we only use 2. Each line has a priority, so when dialing out, it will start by trying the phone in slot 1, then 2 and finally 3. If you don't want to dial out through line 1, then you can dial *2 or *3 and then dial normally and the gateway will dial out through the respectively connected phone (all explained in the instructions). We both use the Blackberry 8330 Curve, which each use Bluetooth version 2.0. We keep our gateway in the bedroom since that is the most convenient place for us and we get a full strength tower signal throughout our house. There is a usefulness of placing it in a room that gets the best tower signal and then connecting your phone line from there (i.e. bedroom 1 gets no signal, but bedroom 2 gets great signal from the cell towers).You can connect your landline handsets to the gateway in 1 of 2 ways. The simplest method is to plug your phone right into the gateway and since most cordless phones come with multiple handsets, it's very easy to then disperse the extra handsets to convenient places throughout the house. The other method of landline connection involves disconnecting your home from the phone company and then plugging the gateway into any phone jack, which then gives all other phone jacks in your house a connection. I haven't been successful in accomplishing this method, but the telephone we have had 3 different handsets, so it was not a big issue. The disconnect process is not explained by the Xlink company (for liability reasons), but if you search for something like VOIP my house, you'll find it. It is the same process.Since we keep our phones in the same room (approx 6-8 feet) from the Xlink gateway, we have no sound quality problems. If we have our cell phones in a different room than the gateway however, there will be crackling & distortion until we put our cell phones closer to the gateway.One of the great features of this device is it allows my wife and I to be on the same cell phone line at the same time if we need to speak to the same person at the same time.There are a few quirks I've found, but don't really bother me and I still give it a 5 star rating.1. When your cell phone is out of range of the gateway, the corresponding light/button on top will blink until it is back in range. (You can click the light/button and it will shut off, but that means it will not reconnect when the phone is back in range, unless you click it again)2. While you can use a built in address book feature to dial out on land line handsets, it will only work on the first cell phone connected, so consider which phone should be connected in slot 1, 2 and 3 (i.e. Phone 1 can dial out using built in address book, but phone 2 can't dial out using the built in address book when phone 1 is in range, you have to dial *2 then the phone number (manually) to dial out when phone 1 is connected).3. The light buttons on top are a fairly bright blue. That may bother some people, but not us.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-17: Easy to set up and connects easily and automatically to my cell phone (Samsung Galaxy S4). I haven't tried using multiple cell lines. I love that the land-line phone rings like a regular land line, and I love that I can dial out with an antique rotary phone. It's like it's 1950 again at my desk. But the audio quality is substandard, which seems to be a real issue with Bluetooth; I've had many Bluetooth headsets and almost all of them have bad audio. How difficult can it be, when phone audio is so limited in the bandwidth it needs? It's not like 7-channel movie audio or something. The audio improves after the first few seconds of the call, for whatever reason, and people at the other end sometimes comment on the "bad connection" and sometimes don't. So maybe it's like 1950 again in terms of the audio quality too.

    Rating: 4

    2012-06-23: (Using with iPhones) I discontinued my home phone service and my wife and I just were using our cell phones. I then heard about this type of technology that connected your home land phones with your cell phone. Figured I would give it a try. AWESOME! Just unplug your land phone line from the wall and plug it into this bluetooth. Turn your cell phone bluetooth on discoverable mode. It connects to the Xlink easily and you're ready to go! I read that you want the other version - the "N" version if you want to continue to use a land line phone service at the same time. The only limitation of this unit the bluetooth technology. All bluetooth devices need to be in a decent range of each other to connect. My Xlink is in my kitchen. I start to get a crackle on the line if the phone is ~30 feet away in my bedroom. But anywhere within ~20 feet, the line is clear. Thus I simply leave my phone in this general area. When I want to make a call, I pick up any of the cordless phones I have that are connected to the base (there are 4), and I simply dial. The phone uses the cell every time and makes the call. When receiving a call, the cordless phone displays the caller ID without any problems. This thing is GREAT. Definitely no need for my regular phone service now...**** UPDATE **** UPDATE... WELL, after 6 months of use, my opinion on this has changed. My review above still is valid... It links up just fine with your bluetooth enabled phone as I described and once linked, it works fine. BUT HERE IS THE PROBLEM... Imagine that you're relaxing by the TV and a phone call come in on your cell phone. So you pick up YOUR CELL and answer and start talking. 30 seconds (or other random time) into your conversation, you realize that you cannot hear the other person now! You look down and see that the phone is now connected to the Xlink. You hopefully switch back quick enough before the person on the line gets upset and hangs up...OR you're coming home from work while talking on your cell phone and pull into the garage... and then the Xlink connects and you no longer have the conversation going on your cell. You may be able to click over, but sometimes you don't realize that it has if you are the one talking.Well, this happened to myself and my wife so many times, that we eventually gave up and just TURNED THIS THING OFF. I tried to keep using this for a while... but it became too frustrating!!! I'm too far out of the return period... I wish I would have returned it when I could have.OVERALL, IT'S A GREAT CONCEPT AND MAY WORK WELL AT TIMES, BUT IT WILL BECOME FRUSTRATING FOR YOU IF YOU STILL PLAN TO USE YOUR CELL PHONE FOR A PORTION OF THE TIME. IF YOU WANT TO USE THIS... YOU'LL LIKELY NEED TO SIMPLY PUT YOUR PHONE DOWN NEAR THE XLINK AND *ONLY USE YOUR HOME PHONES*. Unfortunately my initial smart investment has failed and I'm out of luck. BUT luckily I found a good alternative! I use OBI and google voice for my home phone now... works great!OBi110 Voice Service Bridge and VoIP Telephone AdapterIF YOU HAVE ANY QUESTIONS FOR ME, FEEL FREE TO LEAVE A REPLY TO THIS REVIEW AND I'LL GLADLY ANSWER! HOPEFULLY MY EXPERIENCE HAS BEEN HELPFUL FOR YOU!

    Rating: 3

    2014-02-18: Ditch your land line service! Without losing the use of your corded or cordless phone systems at home or in your office. All cell phones with Bluetooth wireless technology will work with XLink. Awesome Product !!!!

    Rating: 5

    2009-04-29: My wife and I got rid of the VoIP service we had since everyone calls our cell phones anyway. But in the new house, there's always quirky spots (my signal is good at my desk, but my new cell phone doesn't realize I answered the call -wierd). And some people reading this may have dead zones. Enter the Xlink.I read about the Panasonic KX-TH1212B in Consumer Reports and saw how they liked it, and I always like Panasonic products. But reading some of the reviews online here, I questioned if I may also experience issues. I then read about the Dock-n-Talk, or whatever it's called, and a GE bluetooth link, but everyone kept swearing by the Xlink.The Xlink worked right out of the box. I put the box at the cell phone chargers, where cell signal is perfect and issue free. I plugged it up to my Panasonic cordless phones (I call them networked - where you have one plugged into jack and others one their charger but not plugged in wall throughout the house), and there have been no issues.When you have the cell phone past the 10ft range from box instructed, you will get some static. Easy solution - move the cell phone into range. I liked that I read you could plug up the box and firmware upgrade at no charge for future cell models.On my cordless handsets, I have numbers programmed, and the handset speaks those names. If an unrecognized call comes in, then it shows up as 'Xlink BT', but I have no issue with that. I bought this fron ANTonline through Amazon, and have had nothing but good things to say.

    Rating: 5

    2010-01-16: I had struggled for over three years trying to get acceptable VOIP performance with my DSL connection from Qwest. For two years, I went back and forth between my VOIP provider (AT&T; Callvantage) and Qwest DSL with no resolution. But since AT&T; was pulling the plug on their VOIP service anyway, I tried Qwest VOIP. Surely since VOIP and DSL were both being provided by the same company, they would get it sorted out. 40 hours of my time, two service visits, multiple hardware reconfigurations, multiple QoS setups; they really tried, but ultimately we both gave up. Even though I had a really clean 3.0 mbps DSL line, somehow it could not support an acceptable phone conversation if anyone on my three computer network was doing anything- just clicking on a webpage was enough to break up the call.I was on the verge of giving up and going back to POTS when I happened across this in a VOIP forum. I'm on a family plan with Verizon and get excellent signal coverage in my home, so I added a line, ported my VOIP number to it and used an older LG cell I had as a dedicated phone for the Xlink. I have it sitting right next to the Xlink and have it plugged into its charger. Works perfectly. And costs me just $12/mo with taxes. Another benefit is when we travel, we just bring the cell with us and can answer calls to our home phone as if we were there. Sound quality has been generally excellent as long as you don't expect miracles- if you are talking to someone on another cell, you are going to have the quality of cell to cell as the best you can expect. But cell to landline calls have been really clear (the LG I'm using has really robust call quality).One final comment to another reviewer, who hoped a future firmware upgrade would provide names on caller ID instead of saying XLink; you have to remember this device is limited to cell phone protocols- cell phones have never provided the names of the callers (unless they're in your phonebook). And there's no consistent way to extract that info from your cell and display it on your home phones. However, if you get a multi-handset portable phone like ones from Panasonic, AT&T; or Uniden, if the number calling is in their shared phonebook then you will see it on your caller ID.(I understated this device may be made by Siemens who has just brought out an identical device with their own name on it. Since Xlink spent the money to pave the way for people to understand and benefit from this technology, I would like to suggest buyers continue to support them by buying their version.)

    2014-07-07: Good product I'm mostly pleased with. Works as promised. Connection quality is contingent with your cellular connection quality. ie: if your cell service connection quality is good it matches up when using a phone connected to the Xlink. If you cell service connection is poor the Xlink connection quality also matches. My cellular service quality in my location is "OK" but not crystal clear, continuously solid, perfect. In short - the Xlink Bluetooth Gateway is great for increasing your usage of your cell phone service. I have it connected to a multi-handset landline cordless phone and it works fine. I can answer my cell phone on any one of them, wherever they are in the house, and the clarity and quality of the call is equal to answering my cell phone. One major advantage is the comparatively better comfort of the landline handsets, which is more ergonomically designed. Disadvantage, of course, is that moving around or going to a "better" location to improve signal quality does nothing when on the Bluetooth connected landline phone handset as the cell phone is what is getting the actual signal and is stationary. All in all - I rate this as an excellent product but only gave it 4 stars because it can't work miracles and improve on what it has to work with (your existing cell service connection quality). Although those lucky enough to have a crystal clear, solid cell connection at their home location would rate a 5 star review, most of us do not so a fair review - though not the shortcoming of the Xlink - is 4 stars, because having a cell service connection is contingent on its use. I do however recommend it except in the worst cellular service connection locations.

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-09: We've been using our Xlink BT for a week now after ditching our landline. Our setup is Xlink + Vtech DECT6 6-handset wireless system + 2 iPhones (4S & 5). The Xlink and Vtech base unit are set up in our kitchen where we get 2-3 bars consistently on AT&T.; We have our chargers right there too. Our 6 wireless handsets on the Vtech are working flawlessly with the Xlink. Set-up was a no-brainer. I upgraded the unit as instructed, via Windows PC, but others have said it wasn't necessary.I want to explain what's happening with Caller ID, because that was a concern for us. CallerID from AT&T; doesnt come thru on our wireless handsets like it (still) does on our iPhones. But if a caller is in our iPhone Contacts, we get the caller name and the number calling us on all 6 handsets on our system. If not, we get "Xlink BT" and the number. So when you get this device, it will force you to tidy up your Contacts and add numbers for people who call you but aren't in there.Call quality has been exactly the same on our home handsets as on our iPhones. No callers have said they were not hearing us well. Our phones quickly reconnect to the system, when we enter the garage. I've also noticed that our connect range seems to be at least 40 feet, but I havent tested the handset call quality at that distance.We love it that now we can voice dial via Siri from 8 phones instead of just our 2 iPhones. And I can even leave my cell in my purse near the base unit to make sure I don't forget to take it with me.We were paying $50 a month for our landline's nonstop telemarketer calls. The Xlink will pay for itself after the first month. Now there's no reason to keep a landline. If you have a security system, get cellular backup. You should have that anyway. It costs us more for monitoring, but is more secure. And you're not duplicating phone service, so that cell phone bill looks more reasonable.I highly recommend Xlink BT. If you already have decent cellular reception in your home or apartment, you won't be disappointed!UPDATE: Just a few days after I wrote the above, my iPhone 5 is not reconnecting with the Xlink when I come back into range. I have to knock a star off my review for that. Now I have to remember to reconnect it, but at least it's in a prominent place where I notice those blue lights. No similar problem with my husband's iPhone 4S. This may be due to the recent Apple iOS update, hard to tell.UPDATE 2: Now a couple days later and iPhone 5 is reconnecting right away with the Xlink after I come back home. I have read that there have been issues with the phone and bluetooth, so I'm upping my review back to 5 stars. Any disconnect I think must be Apple's fault!

    2013-09-08: I currently use this for my whole house telephone system. I tried it twice in the past but never seemed to benefit and work successfully. A while back there was a software upgrade that is currently used in this purchase. Apparently it made all the difference.I had used VoIP, which is a Internet connected phone system rather than the old wired system of AT&T;, technically called a POTS. Comcast is an example of such a service in their phone bundled package. After 8 years of network and local Comcast issues, I gave up on that technology in favor of the full usage of my cell phone only. Xtreme was my most practical choice given what was available and my budget.I improved the performance of my local cell signal, by purchasing a home repeater system, after assuring myself of the functionality of this Bluetooth technology. I connected the output to my base wireless phone system, and now have my whole house phone system working without the bugs I had in the 8 years of VoIP service, and without the wired cost of the At&T; or Verizon charges, assuming you can still find real wired services anymore. I haven't looked back!

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-04: I'm quite interested in antiques. So i purchased myself a rotary phone. Problem is, i don't have a wired phone line that supports rotary phone pulse dialing. I tried getting a magic jack, but of course that doesn't support pulse dialing either. So i eventually bought this. If you want to use a rotary dial phone, this is a great thing to have. I connect Xlink to my cellphone and use the rotary phone to call it. I use the rotary dial to input the number i want to call, and my cell phone, connected by bluetooth, recieves those numbers from Xlink and begins to call. at that point, it works like any other rotary dial phone. When you hang up, it hangs up on the cell phone as well. I've only got a few complaints regarding this product.Pros:-Great if you have a rotary dial phone and only cell phone service available. Or if your phone company doesn't support pulse dialing.Cons:- Poor quality. it's not horrendous, it's manageable. Just irritating to have a small bit of distortion in the phone line. Might be the phone or the bluetooth connection, hard to tell since i've never used this phone on an actual phone line before.- Irritating blinking light. I keep this in my room and i like to keep it on so that if someone calls me, i can hear the phone ringing. Unfortunately, that blinking light irritates the crap out of me when i'm trying to sleep. so i usually end up turning it off, which is unfortunate.

    Rating: 3

    2014-05-07: I had a cobra unit before and bluetooth did not reconnect all the time this one works great with out fail and no problem setting up. good buy

    2013-01-03: It came on timeIt works properlyIt connected my cell in an easy wayNice device to have at home in order to use the cell via cordless phone
